title: Hundreds bid emotional final goodbye at funeral of Game of Thrones star and UK's tallest man Neil Fingleton
text:
Hundreds bid emotional final goodbye at funeral of Game of Thrones star and UK's tallest man Neil Fingleton The 36-year-old suffered a heart attack and died suddenly at his home last month Share By Lucy Clarke-Billings Laura Hill 14:32, 17 MAR 2017 Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Neil Fingleton's cortege travels to the Cathedral Share this video Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Hundreds of mourners turned out to say their final goodbyes to the UK's tallest man Neil Fingleton today. 
Mr Fingleton was just 36 when he suffered a heart attack and died suddenly at his home in Gilesgate, County Durham, last month. 
The 7ft 7in Game of Thrones star's funeral was held at Durham Cathedral. According to reports, every row was full. 
Neil, who had been the UK’s tallest man, found fame as Mag the Mighty in the HBO fantasy series after turning his hand to acting in recent years. 
He had previously built a successful career playing basketball in the United States. 
His family told of their heartache following his death which came just after he had been filming for Game of Thrones in Belfast. Read More Neil found fame as Mag the Mighty in the HBO fantasy series (Photo: Getty) Neil had been filming for Game of Thrones in Belfast just before his untimely death (Photo: HBO) 
Proud mum-of-three Christine, told Chronicle Live from the family home: “He’d never felt better. It’s a dreadful shock, we are just devastated. 
“We have always been a close family. He was very kind and very generous; all of us would say that.” 
While Neil's stature helped him land a role in Game of Thrones, Christine revealed it also came with its difficulties. 
She said: “It would be a struggle at times. It definitely would have been difficult for him but he made the best of things and got on with it.” 
Christine said Neil had been in good health and celebrated his 36th birthday shortly before Christmas. 
“He’d never felt better I don’t suppose,” she said. “He looked forward to going back to filming and he really enjoyed working on Game of Thrones, though I must admit I never watched it myself.” Read More Neil Fingleton was close to his sister Keely and brother Michael (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) Mirror woman Beth Neil met Neil Fingleton and spent the day with him 
Neil became a well-known face on the acting circuit and TV screens across the country, and also took on roles in X-Men: First Class and Jupiter Ascending. 
He spent 10 years playing Stateside and spent two years at the University of North Carolina before transferring to Holy Cross in Massachusetts. 
Christine said: “His coach at Teesside, Tony Hanson, really encouraged him and supported him in his career.” 
But after a successful career playing professionally in Spain, China, Italy, Greece and England, he turned his attention to acting. 
In 2014, Neil played Mag the Mighty in Game of Thrones and the villain The Fisher King in BBC ’s Doctor Who. 
His mum remembers his first gig was playing ‘The Thinker’ in a Muller Light advert. 
“That was really quite good,” Christine said. “It went from there and a lot of people saw him on that.” Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
